The speeches read as follows—
TRADEX SCHEME BILL 1999 [No. 2]

This bill, along with the Tradex Duty Imposition (General) Bill 1999, the Tradex Duty Imposition (Customs) Bill 1999, the Tradex Duty Imposition (Excise) Bill 1999 and the Customs Tariff Amendment (Tradex) Bill 1999 will implement the Government's new Tradex Scheme.

The purpose of these bills is to implement a new tariff export concession scheme to be called Tradex. The Tradex scheme was a key initiative in the Government's Investing for Growth industry statement.

Investing for Growth highlighted that a key driving force behind the growth of world trade in manufactures is an increasing globalisation of corporate production strategies. As a result, various components of final goods tend to be traded several times, with value adding occurring in a number of different locations around the world. This phenomenon is fostering investment in `hub' activities. Our proximity to the Asia Pacific region and other advantages such as low outbound cargo costs, makes Australia well placed to attract this type of investment and to become a regional base for distribution and manufacturing operations.

The Government's industry statement recognised that the competitiveness of Australia's customs regime is an important factor in fostering hub activities. In relation to this, it is necessary to take account of the internationally recognised principle that goods should be taxed only in the country in which they are consumed. There is also a need to ensure that compliance costs incurred by companies in importing and exporting goods are minimised.

The objective of Tradex is to streamline and improve those programs aimed at providing relief to businesses that currently pay customs duty and sales tax on imported products which are re-exported or incorporated into other goods that are exported. It will replace the previous Tariff Export Concession Scheme (TEXCO) and allow many duty drawback users to gain up-front exemption from import duties and sales tax.

The Tradex initiative follows a review of the existing TEXCO and Duty Drawback Schemes which showed that excessive access and compliance costs are denying businesses the chance to recover unnecessary duty and sales tax and impacting on their international competitiveness.

In essence, the Tradex Scheme is designed to address problems associated with the existing TEXCO and Duty Drawback Schemes. In particular, the low utilisation rates and high compliance costs associated with these schemes. It has been estimated that the current levels of utilisation of these schemes is approximately 50 per cent. This equates to over $100 million in customs duty and sales tax that is unclaimed by Australian exporters with the consequential detrimental impact on their international competitiveness.

Under present arrangements, imported goods generally incur a duty liability when they are landed in Australia, and before being used in a manufacturing process prior to export or re-exported in the same condition at a later time. In circumstances where the goods are re-exported the producer uses duty-drawback provisions to claim the import duty and sales tax back. These arrangements for handling temporary imports represent a signifi cant cost and burden for domestic manufacturers who use imports in their exported production.

Exporters who undertake industrial processing of imports prior to export may currently be eligible for up-front exemption from import duties and wholesale sales tax under the TEXCO scheme. However, the TEXCO scheme makes no allowance for imports that are exported in the same condition or that do not fulfil the `industrial processing' requirement.
Tradex will remove the requirement that goods must undergo an industrial process and enable exporters to gain up-front exemption from duty and sales tax for goods exported in the same condition.
Tradex will improve the effectiveness of existing arrangements by:

. moving primarily to an exemption based system, thereby reducing compliance costs for users. A drawback facility will still be available for instances where, at the time of import, it was not known that goods would be re-exported or used as inputs to exports.
. adopting a more light handed approach to access and compliance requirements, and stronger reliance on self assessment and periodic settlement; and
. relaxing some regulatory arrangements relating to eligibility, registration and on-going compliance requirements.
In particular, the legislation for Tradex will:
clearly spell out eligibility criteria so that potential applicants have a degree of certainty as to the conditions they must meet in order to participate in the scheme;
. enable unsuccessful applicants to have a right of review of the relevant adverse decision;
. provide the administrators of the scheme with the appropriate audit and recovery powers and penalty provisions to help ensure compliance.

This bill, and the three associated bills provide for the introduction of new, streamlined arrangements for Australian exporters who import goods for further processing prior to export or re-export goods in the same condition.
Tradex is an acknowledgment of the increasing globalisation of the world economy and will help to improve Australia's attractiveness as an investment destination.
Tradex will provide real benefits to Australia's exporters, and together with the introduction of the Goods and Services Tax, will improve our international competitiveness as a trading nation.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
TRADEX DUTY IMPOSITION (CUSTOMS) BILL 1999
This is the second of three Tradex Duty Imposition Bills, that accompany the Tradex Scheme Bill 1999.

This bill mirrors the Tradex Duty Imposition (General) Bill 1999 and gives the Department of Industry, Science and Resources the ability to recover Tradex Duty where participants fail to export goods in accordance with their undertakings under the provisions of the Tradex Scheme. The Tradex Scheme Bill 1999 sets out the circumstances in which Tradex Duty becomes payable to the Commonwealth and the process for recovering the duty.
This bill imposes the liability in so far as the tax is a duty of customs within the meaning of section 55 of the Constitution.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
TRADEX DUTY IMPOSITION (EXCISE) BILL 1999
This is the third of three Tradex Duty Imposition Bills, that accompany the Tradex Scheme Bill 1999.

This bill mirrors the Tradex Duty Imposition (General) Bill 1999 and the Tradex Duty Imposition (Customs) Bill 1999 and gives the Department of Industry, Science and Resources the ability to recover Tradex Duty where participants fail to export goods in accordance with their undertakings under the provisions of the Tradex Scheme. The Tradex Scheme Bill 1999 sets out the circumstances in which Tradex Duty becomes payable to the Commonwealth and the process for recovering the duty.
This bill imposes the liability in so far as the tax is a duty of excise within the meaning of section 55 of the Constitution.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
TRADEX DUTY IMPOSITION (GENERAL) BILL 1999
This is the first of three Tradex Duty Imposition Bills, that accompany the Tradex Scheme Bill 1999.

This bill gives the Department of Industry, Science and Resources the ability to recover Tradex Duty where participants fail to export goods in accordance with their undertakings under the provisions of the Tradex Scheme. In particular, Tradex Duty becomes payable when goods imported under the scheme are:
. consumed or used by the Tradex Order Holder in Australia;
. disposed of by the Holder to another person in Australia for the purposes of being consumed or used;
. unable to meet the requirements of the Drawback Regulations under Section 168 of the Customs Act 1901; or
. not exported within one year after importation.

The Tradex Scheme Bill 1999 sets out the circumstances in which Tradex Duty becomes payable to the Commonwealth and the process for recovering the duty. This bill imposes the liability in so far as the tax is neither a duty of customs nor a duty of excise within the meaning of section 55 of the Constitution.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
CUSTOMS TARIFF AMENDMENT (TRADEX) BILL 1999
This is one of five bills designed to give effect to the Government's new Tradex Scheme, a key initiative in the Investing for Growth industry statement.

The other bills which comprise the Tradex package, and which were introduced into the House of Representatives on 14 October 1999, are the Tradex Scheme Bill 1999, the Tradex Duty Imposition (General) Bill 1999, the Tradex Duty Imposition (Customs) Bill 1999 and the Tradex Duty Imposition (Excise) Bill 1999.
The effect of this particular bill is to provide a "free" rate of duty for goods imported under a tradex order.
I commend the bill.

debateinfo.title: EQUAL OPPORTUNITY FOR WOMEN IN THE WORKPLACE AMENDMENT BILL 1999

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 25 November, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.
(Quorum formed)

talk.start.para: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity to deal with this matter in the second reading debate. It gives me an opportunity to highlight not only a number of concerns with respect to the Equal Opportunity for Women in the Workplace Amendment Bill 1999 but also issues that it canvasses which relate to other legislation being considered by the Senate. Let me focus firstly on this bill.

speech.para: Labor, as I am sure previous speakers have indicated, will be opposing those areas where the bill seeks to weaken the current act. The approach by the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business to the legislation and to the current act is very concerning. He seems to have used this review as an opportunity—as he has done in many other areas—to limit prescription where it works in the favour of employers and, as we are aware, in all other areas he is seeking to impose more prescription when it is in the interests of workers or employees. The first point to highlight is where the minister is seeking to limit the prescription on employers, which is the main area that Labor will be opposing. There are also other issues in this legislation which we will be highlighting as well.

Firstly, and strangely for a bill with a short title of Equal Opportunity for Women in the Workplace Amendment Bill 1999 , it will weaken the requirement of employers to promote equal opportunity, which is the current phrase in the act, and replace it to read just, `contribute to the achievement of'. The point here may well be that it is not solely an employer's responsibility to promote equal opportunity. I think everyone in this chamber would accept that it is also the government's responsibility to promote equal opportunity. Let us consider one example where it is obvious that that is what the government is not doing. In another bill currently before us, the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 , the government is seeking to remove workers' entitlements from awards with respect to maternity leave.

The government is going to be removing some of the standard maternity leave provisions from awards, again in the climate of wanting to limit prescription on employers, with the very strange argument, given all of the evidence we have had, particularly after an inquiry by the Sex Discrimination Commissioner, that pregnant women are going to be in a position to bargain above that minimum for themselves.

talk.start.para: —I am sure young women in the gallery are interested in that, Senator Collins.

—From my perspective, Senator Crossin, I am probably in a reasonable position to negotiate some standards in relation to maternity protection, but from my life experience I know a lot of women who are not. I take this opportunity to highlight what was close to the saddest evidence which we heard in our inquiry on the more jobs, better pay bill. The Sex Discrimination Commissioner said that in her inquiry on pregnancy and work she was aware of examples where workers dealing with the effects of these supposedly wonderful family friendly Australian workplace agreements had terminated pregnancy because they could not manage a pregnancy and work. That is how bad workplace relations are in this country at the moment.

speech.para: Let me go back to what is titled the Equal Opportunity for Women in the Workplace Amendment Bill 1999 and highlight the other areas where these proposals are weakening protection for Australian women. The other prescription that the minister proposes to remove from the current legislation is the requirement that employers should consult their employees. So we are going to make it easier for employers to maintain this myth that they are really doing something of benefit for their employees. We are not going to even require that before they report to government that they are doing something about equal opportunity, they talk to their own staff about it. We are going to make it very easy for an employer to simply tick a box and say, `Yes, some vague idea about equal opportunity has occurred in my mind over the last 12 months.' Tick a box, send it off to the government, and that is it. That perhaps best characterises what this bill is about.

This bill represents the result of a review which was part of the 1995 Competition Principles Agreement and a review of all legislation that is costly to business. That is the purpose of this bill: simply to limit any regulation or prescription that might be costly to business. But the sad thing is that a lot of discriminatory behaviour is costly to business. We used to have in place guidelines and prescriptions that helped business make some cultural change and hopefully realise over time that many of their practices were costing them in the long term. Again, perhaps the best example is that of pregnancy and work, because unfortunately only a very small number of employers have started realising that, if they find incentives to encourage their professional, well-trained, skilled women to return after a pregnancy, if they help them find ways of working within their business and if they introduce real workplace family-friendly practices, their employees do come back and they do not lose those skills. The employers maintain a skilled work force and they do not have the costs associated with employees moving on and a high turnover. This act was about achieving that cultural change.

This bill tries to remove all those guides. It is removing very simple guides like `We suggest you actually talk to your own employees about what they think might be useful to generate some workplace flexibility that would suit them, that would help them balance their work and family lives.' Let me have a look at another example which highlights that point. One of the prescriptions in the current act that this bill seeks to remove is the requirement for a senior manager within a firm to coordinate the development of the affirmative action plan. Why is that so unreasonable? If an employer is meant to be reporting to government that they are genuinely trying to do something in this area, what is so difficult about requiring that a senior manager within the company has some responsibility for it? It is a fact of life that if it is not a senior manager, no change is really happening or going to happen. Again, it highlights what is so limited about this bill.

You can argue that there are some things that impose, particularly on small businesses, some difficult prescriptions, such as regular reporting requirements and some requirements in relation to the detail of reporting. But this bill also seeks to remove a review of report. The level of activity is currently scaled to get some idea of what is going on in Australian businesses. Also, there are requirements that certain issues be reported on to get, again, some idea of what is really going on in Australian businesses. The real motive for removing this, apart from the fact that some businesses do genuinely struggle to deal with these reporting criteria, is that, as in other areas such as the Workplace Relations Act, the minister does not want to know. The minister does not want to know how Australian workplace agreements are really working for workers.

The minister has so far—after about two years of operations of Australian workplace agreements—through the Office of the Em ployment Advocate, conducted research into how employers find these agreements work, but they have never inquired seriously, in any objective and broad sense, about how these agreements work for employees. I would go further than that and say that the minister has deliberately sought to conceal how these agreements are really working for employees. Despite overwhelming anecdotal evidence from a variety of areas, including legitimate statutory authorities such as the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, the minister and his department continue to exist in a massive state of denial—a massive state of denial that will be highlighted next week when we report on our intensive inquiry into the operations of the Workplace Relations Act. The very sad thing is that it seems that government senators are also in that state of absolute denial.

Ultimately, it is those government senators and members who continue in that denial who are going to have to live with the consequences, and the best news we have had recently on that score is the impact that has been felt most seriously in Victoria. The Kennett government stumbled because it had been in denial about the very extreme effects that its activities have had on everyday people.

When we get to the committee stage of debating this legislation, which I understand will not be today, I will concentrate particularly on amendments that we will be proposing in two areas. The first of those areas will be to strengthen provisions in the bill that deal with the consultation component because the genuineness of this legislation is seriously under question unless there is a guide that workers be consulted about equal opportunity programs. But, hell, why ask women about what they think will help them maintain their employment? That seems to be the minister's view. In fact, it is with some humour that I look at the title of this bill. I actually characterise it with another title, which I will come to in a moment because it has slipped my mind.

The government and the minister cannot be serious. They talk about changing the title from the Affirmative Action Agency to Equal Opportunity for Women in the Workplace Agency, but really it is about less prescription and about reducing costs for business in the short term. I hope, before I finish my 20 minutes, I remember how I characterised this bill because it amused me for half the day. I suppose in late term pregnancy one's short-term memory starts disappearing, but I hope I will get back to it.

Let me move on to the other area I was proposing to highlight, again mentioning the pregnancy component, because I intend to spend some time dealing with our view that the HREOC report and some of its recommendations about work and pregnancy or being pregnant and productive should be considered seriously by the government. We have mentioned in our review of the current Workplace Relations Act our disappointment that the government has not yet picked up those recommendations. We are using this opportunity to again highlight those recommendations, and we will be moving some amendments which are tailored to address those recommendations as well. I have already expressed my disappointment that some of the amendments in the Workplace Relations Act actually go backwards, away from the HREOC recommendations, rather than forwards by proposing some real improvements for pregnant women and work.

Just to highlight a couple of those issues, whilst we support the provisions in this bill that look at broadening the definition of employment matters so that we will be covering more employees when dealing with equal opportunity type issues, we want to clarify coverage of the Sex Discrimination Act for federal statutory authorities, judicial office holders and—shock!—members of parliament. So let us hope that we might be able to do something here for members of parliament.

talk.start.para: —I hope we have the support of Jackie Kelly.

—I hope that we do have Jackie Kelly's support, but on top of that I would like the minister's support. I would like to be able to make the decision about when I commence my own maternity leave, and if the government would convince us that they are going to do as we recommend and withdraw the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (More Jobs, Better Pay) Bill 1999 from its priority list, I would actually be able to commence my leave, but the minister is not prepared to do that at this stage. Again, one needs a sense of humour to operate in this place.
—He is being partisan Pete.
—He certainly is being partisan Pete. After I read the Victorian government's submission to our inquiry on the Workplace Relations Act—
—Which government?
—The new government's submission; we did not have one from the old government. It was actually not so much partisan Pete any more but Pete the—
—Don't be unparliamentary.
—No, I was not going to be unparliamentary; it was Pete the perverter of justice.
—That is an unacceptable way of referring to a member of another place. It is casting some sort of aspersion on him. I ask you to withdraw it.

—I am sorry and I withdraw it. I will reflect it very accurately by quoting their submission, which is public, which said that they thought the minister's behaviour with respect to Victorian employees was `perverse'.

speech.para: I will close by again highlighting that our amendments will be dealing with quite a number of issues to try to improve this bill, to re-insert some things that have been recommended to the minister but he has ignored—copious amounts of advice that should be a component of an effective equal opportunity regime. We will be forcing the minister to reconsider those issues. Unfortunately, the minister is not really about equal opportunity for women in this bill; he is about removing prescription for business, and when we get to the committee stage I am sure I will recall the characterisation I had for this bill earlier in the day and I will share that humour with the Senate.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, on the Equal Opportunity for Women in the Workplace Amendment Bill 1999 . I do so specifically on behalf of my colleague Senator Andrew Murray, who has responsibility within the Democrats for this legislation. He is not able to be here at the moment but he will still be having carriage of the bill for the Democrats when we get to the committee stage of the debate, whether that is next week or next year.

speech.para: It is appropriate to make some comments at this stage before we get into consideration of the detail of the bill and of some of the amendments that are going to be put forward in terms of the fundamental principle of equal opportunity for women in the workplace. It is appropriate for me, as an Australian Democrat, to emphasise the strong record that the Democrats have had over many years in promoting equal opportunity for women in the workplace and elsewhere as a crucial principle not just of justice but—as indeed has been shown through studies over the recent years since there has been some improvement in opportunities for women—the economic advantages to the country.

It is not always desirable to reduce such social justice principles to economic measurements in dollars and cents. Nevertheless, I think this shows the good sense in enabling all people to contribute as effectively and as fully as possible whether it is in the workplace or in the broader community. It is in all Australians' interests, not just the interests of individual women, to ensure that women have equal opportunity in the workplace not just for the benefit of women but for the benefit of all of us both socially and economically. It is self-evident that women bring enormous skills, expertise, perspectives and experience to the workplace and it really goes against everyone's self-interest to try to minimise in any way the ability of women to contribute or to minimise the opportunity for that contribution to be maximised. So it is both economically sensible, as well as an important basic principle of equity, to ensure that women do have equal opportunity in the workplace and, as many other speakers have indicated in this debate, that is a goal that has not yet been fulfilled and indeed is under threat in some areas.

This bill obviously relates to issues in the workplace and I had the opportunity to attend a few of the public hearings that were recently held into the broader workplace relations legislation that Minister Reith has put forward and also to read a reasonable proportion of the public submissions. Certainly, one of the clear messages that came through and continues to come through—and there were quite a lot of clear messages in the public hearings and in the submissions about that particular bill—is that some issues of equal opportunity for women in the workplace are under threat in terms of how workplaces operate in Australia and some of the trends in their operations. We need to be aware of the threat, to spotlight the reasons for it and to try to ensure that that reversal is addressed.

A whole range of issues continue to present problems and obstacles for women in the workplace, whether they are in the area of sexual discrimination and harassment and the inadequacies of processes to deal with those, or relate to such issues as pregnancy and maternity leave in the workplace. Information and stories came forward from women concerned about what it may mean if they get pregnant and take time off or wish to take time off to have a child: whether or not they will get their job back, whether or not their responsibilities will be the same as before they left and whether or not their career path opportunities will be curtailed as part of having a child and expanding their family.

That is a very real fear amongst many women and it is certainly a fear that the Democrats believe should not be present. There should be a very clear-cut principle that having a child and going on maternity leave does not present to someone a threat as to their being able to return to their previous position, not just in terms of issues such as pay rates and entitlements but also in terms of responsibility: the types of work they are able to do and the career paths and opportunities open to them. Speaking personally and also for the Democrats, that is a fundamental principle that is not always upheld and it needs to be stated as strongly and as often as possible because that threat is still present. Clearly, things have moved forward from the days when women basically had to resign from their jobs, including those in the public service, if they got pregnant. Whilst we have moved on from those days, there is still some way to go before we reach the perfect outcome, and those sorts of issues need to be recognised.

Perhaps one of the biggest aspects of the workplace and employment market which puts some of the advances women have made over recent years under greater threat is a move towards an increase in casual and temporary work. Very clear information and evidence came to light through the Senate inquiry into the Workplace Relations Bill that an increase in—and quite a deliberate use of—casual, temporary and part-time work by employers puts the rights of employees at much greater risk and very much increases the pressure on individual employees to sacrifice basic entitlements to ensure that they are able to maintain work, and that has a particular impact on women.

It is no secret that the greater proportion of women are going into casual and part-time work. In terms of areas of jobs growth, those areas are more and more often filled by women rather than men, and a much greater proportion of women are in casual and part-time work. That can suit people's circumstances, obviously. It is not to suggest that such work is a second-class type of employment, but it does present special challenges and difficulties in terms of protecting and safeguarding the entitlements of all workers who are engaged in casual work and also part-time work. Those safeguards are in danger of diminishing, and that presents particular difficulties for women.

So, whilst there have been advances, and ones that the Democrats have championed and welcomed over time moving towards greater opportunity for women in the workplace, not only is there still some way to go but also we have to guard against slipping back. I think there is a risk of slipping back and losing some of the advances that have been made in recent years. The Democrats, both as part of examining this legislation in further detail and the amendments that will be brought forward and more generally as a general principle with all legislation, will be vigilant in ensuring that the gains that have been made in the past are not lost and that the goals that still need to be met will be advanced towards. I am sure that Senator Murray will continue in a similar vein when the amendments are considered in greater detail in the committee stage.

talk.start.para: —I thank all of those honourable senators who contributed to this very important debate on this important piece of legislation. I thank Senator Bartlett for filling the place on the speakers' list left by his colleague Senator Murray, who was unable to contribute this afternoon but whom we expect to contribute in his constructive manner when the committee stages of the Equal Opportunity for Women in the Workplace Amendment Bill 1999 are dealt with. I indicate also that the government does not intend continuing to a committee stage this afternoon in the limited time available, and so people will have time to further consider amendments to the bill.

speech.para: As I said, the issues that have been canvassed in the debate are important. The government is committed to designing an equal opportunity regime for the new millennium. We currently have a regime in Australia that was designed some decades ago. We believe it is time to look forward. Our approach to equal opportunity in the workplace is not a single-faceted, prescriptive legislative focus; it is an across the economy focus. We all know that in an economy where you have jobs growth, where you have low interest rates and low inflation, the opportunities and the choices for women in the workplace are going to be a lot wider than if you have a contracting economy, high interest rates, high debt and not very many job opportunities.

One of the great achievements for women of this government is to ensure that they have choice again in their lives. Women with children have special responsibilities, as do fathers. It is an economy where we have interest rates under control. You see a very big change from a decade ago under the previous administration, where you had interest rates in many cases going over 20 per cent, which meant that many women who did not want to be in the work force had no choice but to go into the work force simply to meet the financial needs of their families, because if the women did not go into the work force they would not have been able to pay the higher mortgage interest rates that were forced on them by the massive debt that was run up by the previous administration. In the Hawke and the Keating years tens of billions of dollars of deficits year on year on year drove interest rates up, drove the cost of housing up and forced many women, against their own will, to go into the work force just to pay those mortgage interest bills.

So this government is interested in reforming the legislative regime, which is what we are focusing on in this debate, but we are also interested in having a broader approach to equal opportunity, and that is to create true economic opportunity and true choice for women through sound economic management which delivers low interest rates, low debt, higher real wages, high productivity and more and more jobs. What a fantastic thing it was yesterday to hear the Treasurer in the other place able to announce in his midyear economic review that we can now see the unemployment rate going below seven per cent next year and strong economic growth—all on the back of historic low interest rates so that living is more affordable. What a great thing for Australian families and Australian women.
It is my sincere pleasure to again thank all honourable senators for their commitment to this debate and to commend the bill to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —Earlier this month the Chairman and Chief Executive of News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch, addressed the Australasia Centre annual dinner. In my view, Mr Murdoch's address was in essence endorsing an all but amoral approach to foreign policy, and more particularly to Australia's stance in East Timor. Mr Murdoch used Australia's participation in East Timor as a case in point, obviously coming down on the side that Australia should not be involved in East Timor. While he did not say it straight out, that was obviously the summation by those present and how the media publicised it.

speech.para: Those who read Mr Murdoch's address will see that he shrouds his true sentiments towards East Timor in a very broad analysis of the perils of moral crusades and the virtues of financial interest. To quote from Mr Murdoch's speech:
In short, if Australia chooses to pursue a moralistic foreign policy, it had better realise it runs the risk of doing more harm than good.

It is one thing to put young Australian lives at risk under Australian commanders and pursuant to Australian rules of engagement. It is quite another to place them in harm's way under rules set by someone not democratically elected and responsible to their parents and loved ones for their safety.

None of this means that Australia should adopt a coldly amoral foreign policy. Rather, we must always remember four values, but at the same time we must take a hard-headed view of where interests lie.

Mr Murdoch calls for a cool-headed and a hard-headed approach to the East Timor question, which he claims Australia did not take. Rather, he says in his address, Australia reacted with emotionalism, moralism and even religious enthusiasm—all to be taken as a flaw in national character, I suppose.

Behind these accusations of Australia's misadventure, a certain barefaced self-interest is obvious and leaves him open to the accusation of a very fake concern for Australia's interests. His massive investments in Indonesia and the Asia-Pacific region, no less than Star television, and his own ethical code that gravitated him towards the 30-year Suharto dictatorship betray his bottom line interests against East Timor.

Murdoch's own militia have been out in force razing the government's recently announced policy to lift the Medicare levy so as to fund Australia's East Timor commitment. Murdoch journalist and most noted Suharto apologist, Greg Sheridan, declared emotively that the government's Timor levy is a `bad, dangerous gimmick'. It is not surprising that this journalist, having spent his career justifying the Indonesian occupation of and brutality in East Timor, would revert to denigrating the necessary policy moves to defend and construct an independent East Timor. Of the myriad articles written by Mr Sheridan, I can safely say he never acknowledged the self-serving nature of the Suharto family, nor did Mr Sheridan ever trust that democracy could achieve more for Indonesia than the 32-year totalitarian regime. Now he and his boss deride this government's actions to bring peace, stability, democracy and a future to this new country.

In its most narrow interpretation, Mr Murdoch's address is right if we are talking in purely economic terms. It would be much more financially viable and economically responsible to turn a blind eye to the atrocities committed, but it would also be morally damning for a country such as Australia. Such hand washing has a way of sticking to a country's history. It is my view that Mr Murdoch creates a false dichotomy between morality and the national interest. The distinction between the two is not black and white.
Former White House Deputy Secretary of Defense, Joseph Nye, put it well when he said:
A democratic definition of the national interest does not accept the distinction between a morality-based and an interest-based foreign policy. Moral values are simply intangible interests.

It is worth noting that this parliament unanimously believes Australia has a compelling strategic interest in promoting peace and security in East Timor as it moves towards independence. Our leadership of INTERFET in East Timor is not only about human rights and the defence of people seeking a just freedom; it is equally about looking after our own defence and security. Without peace and stability in East Timor, Australia cannot be confident of the long-term security of its northern borders.

It is true to say that the moral aspect weighed heavily in the decision to take up the lead of an international peace force. After all, the Indonesian forces had failed to control the violence and butchery of the innocent by the militia—and, indeed, the military's own who involved themselves in razing buildings and slaughtering the innocent.

Not only did the international community, through the United Nations, support Australia's actions, but 18 other countries have deployed their forces or are committed to INTERFET. Those countries are Brazil, Canada, Denmark, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Malaysia, New Zealand, Norway, the Philippines, Portugal, the Republic of Korea, Singapore, Thailand, the United Kingdom and the United States—countries arguably more motivated by morality than national security.

It is ironic that Mr Murdoch should criticise Australia's actions as being a knee-jerk response when recommending Australia should act only after a full and open debate on the matter and then deliver our answer, when in fact the main concerns at Australia's actions were that we did not act swiftly enough. Of course, both criticisms are wrong. Australia acted according to the United Nations directions, and acted swiftly and according to the gravity of the situation post referendum. The Senate need only recall the rampaging of the militia to reject any proposition that we acted in a knee-jerk fashion.

Mr Murdoch's bottom-line concern that Australia's peacekeeping effort will cost billions of dollars can be answered by saying that the price for our international responsibilities—or any country's for that matter—is unavoidably expensive. But why hasn't Mr Murdoch acknowledged in his speech that most of this expense is attributed to the then Indonesian government, or elements within that government, and the military's involve ment in the scorched earth policy in East Timor, even if it was only to have waved the militia through on their rampaging way?

The scorched earth policy, which saw 70 per cent of public buildings and private residences in East Timor destroyed, as well as 75 per cent of the population being displaced, has multiplied the cost of rebuilding East Timor and, subsequently, Australia's aid costs. Also, the insecurity created by an unchecked militia required a larger than anticipated peacekeeping force, pushing up the cost of our engagement. Yet Mr Murdoch's speech meticulously avoids any reference to Indonesia's responsibility, as if to say they have none.

But the greatest gall must come from the claim by the elements inside Jakarta's hierarchy and their Australian supporters that we have something to apologise for in how we have undertaken our INTERFET responsibilities—that is, that we have been insensitive and heavy-handed towards Indonesian sensitivities. In response to that, on any analysis, under General Cosgrove the force have carried out their duties masterfully and in an extremely dangerous situation. By meeting force with force they have better secured their own and the people of East Timor's well-being, which is their very mission. It is not in Australia's interest—morally, financially, or strategically—to accept Mr Murdoch's view as outlined in his address.

talk.start.para: —I rise this afternoon to place on record my response and a number of comments in relation to a speech given by Senator Grant Tambling, the other senator for the Northern Territory, on Wednesday when he rose in this chamber to address the matter of indigenous education in the Northern Territory. Let me say at the outset that I found his contribution extremely disappointing because of not only the facts he presented in his speech but also the manner in which it was delivered.

speech.para: In that speech he made reference to me showing some surprising ignorance in relation to Aboriginal education. I would like to place on record that no such ignorance has been displayed, other than by Senator Tambling in that speech. Senator Tambling has made a number of very good contributions in this chamber and has spoken on a number of topics on which he is well versed, but his speech on Wednesday has shown that education is not one of those.

Having had over 20 years experience in the education industry and having taught in an Aboriginal school in the Northern Territory in bilingual education and having been employed 12 years ago to write the first lot of performance indicators for the Department of Education under their AEP, Aboriginal Education Program—or, IESIP, as it is known now—I would hope that I bring to this chamber anything but ignorance. Senator Tambling's ignorance, of course, went to the tune that all through his speech he mispronounced the acronym `IESIP'. This is probably very hard for our Hansard reporters to encapsulate in the written record of the Senate, but that in fact could be attributed to his lack of knowledge of the subject.

But what needs to be said about Wednesday's speech is that between the Northern Territory government, Senator Tambling and the federal Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs somebody needs to get their story right. Senator Tambling was busy trying to defend the actions of his colleagues in the Territory but, in fact, at this stage all three are not singing the same tune. Their facts are not consistent. Let me draw your attention to one example. In Senator Ellison's speech on Monday in response to my contribution he said that this government—that is, the federal government—since coming to power had in fact commissioned a report that was carried out by Mr Collins, insinuating that Learning Lessons was something that the federal government had commissioned.

Yet the response on Wednesday in the Northern Territory tabled by the Minister for School Education, Peter Adamson—who I might say at this stage is probably doing an even worse job in education than the muddle-headed duck out of Beatrix Potter would do—referred to the review being commissioned by the Northern Territory Department of Education. So who, in fact, did commission Bob Collins and that report? Perhaps it is time that some of the people in this scenario got their story right.

Senator Tambling also went on to say that the purpose of the IESIP review was to `reorganise and rationalise the current collection of 32 initiatives' by the Northern Territory government. That is not what they think. The front of the review of their IESIP report actually says that this is about the future of the current IESIP initiatives and their future programs for the year 2000. Recommendation No. 1 is that all 32 initiatives cease.

On one hand we have the Northern Territory government saying one thing, and on the other hand we have Senator Tambling saying something else. But in fact the Commonwealth government and Minister Kemp are on record in the Northern Territory for not exactly supporting the Northern Territory government. So I am surprised that Senator Tambling would go out of his way to do that.

In an interview conducted by Drive Time on 22 October of this year, of which I have the transcript, Senator Kemp was asked at length by the reporter about his response to the review of IESIP. The reporter mentioned that Senator Kemp had in fact travelled to the Tiwi Islands with Bob Collins while he was conducting the review. These are the words of David Kemp:
. . . the Tiwi Islanders said to us then that they believed that they had been failed by the education system. It is clear—
he said—
that there is a major problem with indigenous education . . .
He further went on to say:
It's clear that many of these children are not getting the basic literacy and numeracy skills . . .
Julie Christiansen, the reporter, asked:
He—
Bob Collins—
described it as an appalling crisis. Would you put it as strongly as that?
David Kemp's response was:
Well I think it's totally unacceptable in Australia that we've got such a large group of young Australians who aren't being adequately served by the Education system that's been provided.

So we have an admission by the Commonwealth and, as I said on Monday, a willingness by the Commonwealth to actually try to step in and do something to assist the embarrassing and national disgrace in relation to Aboriginal education in the Northern Territory.

The further point I want to come to this afternoon is the funding arrangements under IESIP. Senator Tambling said that I made a statement that the current operational plan as negotiated with the Commonwealth will simply be extended to the year 2000, and he said that that was incorrect. It is not incorrect, Senator Tambling, and I am most surprised that you do not have your facts right. Perhaps you should stop getting the people in the Northern Territory government or their spin doctors to write your speeches for you. In fact, in relation to the Indigenous Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1999 , the Bills Digest provided by the Parliamentary Library says this:
The most prominent changes were:
. the current triennial funding for 1997-99 to be extended by 1 year so that from 2001 IESIP could operate on quadrennial funding, in alignment with the Commonwealth's major schools funding programs
So, Senator Tambling, I was not incorrect. In fact, I was very correct, in accordance with the second reading speech, the explanatory memorandum and the Bills Digest produced by this parliament.
Senator Tambling further said that I had made a comment about the on-costs taken by the Northern Territory government in the following words:
. . . 46.1 per cent of the total money coming from the Commonwealth is taken off under the guise of on-costs by the Northern Territory government.

He said that this is untrue. Again, Senator Tambling, you are wrong—very, very wrong. I was quoting from a reply to a question on notice that I had from DETYA. It is question No. E490. I had asked DETYA the following question:
The Northern Territory government maintains a high percentage of its funding every three years for the administration costs, around 48%.
(a) Has the department ever looked at how they reached that figure . . .

I went on to ask the department how it was broken down and whether or not it was justified. Their response was that they did have that information. The Northern Territory Department of Education IESIP operational plan for 1997-99 outlines how it applies an administrative levy to salary costs from the IESIP. It breaks those down as being: superannuation 15.6 per cent, workers compensation insurance two per cent, long service leave 2.5 per cent, property management if applicable 14 per cent, administration 12 per cent, a total of 46.1 per cent. The DETYA response goes on to say:

On-costs are only levied against the salary provision in initiatives with part-time workers levied for Superannuation and Workers Compensation. On-costs are not charged on capital or operational area initiatives.
But the figure of 46.1 per cent is fact, from an answer from DETYA to a question on notice. The figure I quoted is not untrue.

Senator Tambling goes on to talk about the IESIP review team's interpretation of `supplementary' and `core'. His speech shows a significant lack of knowledge about the difference between these two. The Northern Territory government's own review clearly talks about the fact that the IESIP money was meant to be supplementary money but had been used over those years as core funding.

There are many elements of Senator Tambling's contribution that are incorrect. In the report that was tabled in the Northern Territory parliament by Peter Adamson on Wednesday in response to the Collins report, only 108 of the 151 recommendations were mentioned—a continuing example of their lack of concern in this area. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to pay tribute to all those who have been involved in the safe haven project for the Kosovars and the East Timorese. The assessment of a community's humanity is the way in which we treat our fellow human beings. Australia as a nation can be very proud of its humane response to the crises of Kosovo and East Timor. A nation cannot respond to human tragedy on this scale without the support of its people. The Australian people deserve to be recognised for their generosity, their concern and their rapid response to those two very significant human tragedies.

speech.para: The calls from the United Nations for assistance in providing sanctuary to the displaced people in Kosovo and East Timor were responded to. We all watched the crisis unfold in Kosovo on our televisions and in our newspapers over a number of weeks during the Christmas season. We saw the exodus of men, women and children packed into carts, on tractors and on foot. Few of us will forget the image of elderly people being wheeled out of Kosovo in wheelbarrows. As they travelled to the border camps in Macedonia, they captured our hearts and captured the hearts of all Australians. The Prime Minister and his fellow ministers, the Minister for Defence, Mr Moore, and Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Philip Ruddock, heeded this unprecedented call from the United Nations for assistance in this world crisis.

The commitment made by the Australian government to help was the first step in a momentous task that involved not just the Commonwealth government across a number of departments. I also pay tribute to all the state governments and agencies that were involved—in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania and Western Australia. Agencies such as health, dental services and education departments became involved in what was a mighty effort, and it is still going on. Non-government organisations rallied at a day's notice. Charitable organisations, community groups, sporting clubs, youth organisations—a plethora of groups—came to the assistance of those groups of people. Families and individuals just fronted up to assist. There are too many to mention by name.

The decision to provide safe haven to 4,000 Kosovar men, women and children unfolded to become the largest humanitarian effort since the Second World War to be undertaken by the Australian government and the Australian people. The compassion and generosity of the Australian people came as no surprise to me, given my portfolio responsibilities as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. Australia is one of the world's most humanitarian nations. Australians have a big heart when it comes to people in need. At over $US9.5 million per annum, Australia is in the top 12 donor countries to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees. It is also one of the top three countries of refugee resettlement, and one of only 10 countries worldwide that even has a designated humanitarian immigration program.

However, even armed with these humanitarian statistics, I was constantly amazed and very often overwhelmed by people's contribution of time—days, nights and weekends; by people volunteering in their holidays; by young Army reservists who appeared and said they wanted to work in the safe havens; by the heartfelt care; by the professionalism of the doctors; and by the cooks. I have to add here that one of the companies in Tasmania that had quoted to provide food for the Kosovars in the safe haven in Brighton, Tasmania realised some way into the program that he had overquoted, and so he reduced his quote. What an example of integrity in business, that he should actually reduce his quote and say that he could do it for less. I ate there, and I can tell you that there was nothing spared on the food and the catering in that organisation. I pay tribute to that gentleman in particular, whom I had the very great fortune of meeting when I presented certificates to all those involved in the Brighton safe haven.

All the workers, paid and unpaid, put in enormous amounts of effort. As principal patron of all the safe havens, I travelled to every haven and to some on a number of occasions. I will be visiting East Hills next week to meet the East Timorese who are there. At the request of the minister, I went to Leeuwin in Western Australia, to Bandiana in the Albury-Wodonga area on the Victoria-New South Wales border, to East Hills in Sydney, to Brighton in Tasmania, to Hampstead in South Australia, to Singleton in the Hunter Valley, and to Portsea and Puckapunyal in Victoria.

The other thing that should not be forgotten is the way in which the local communities came around and assisted as well, some bringing donations of food, others offering buses to take people from Puckapunyal to various sites around Victoria. I cannot tell you all the sorts of support that were given, with sporting clubs taking Kosovars or East Timorese off to various sporting events and so on.

The management of Operation Safe Haven was and still is an enormous exercise for both the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and the Department of Defence, with the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs as lead department. Establishing suitable accommodation for families in what were essentially Army barracks was a huge logistical exercise that demanded cross-departmental cooperation. That came in spades. It was tremendous to see those departments, with very different cultures—as I have said here on previous occasions in this chamber—coming together and being able to work so successfully together.

I am reminded of a comment made when I first visited the Puckapunyal safe haven. One of the Army officers said to me that, after many years of state-of-the-art logistics training, it was great to finally be able to put their skills to good use. One of the other joys was to see a young Army reservist, who was Albanian, playing with the Kosovar children, and to see them getting rid of the fear that they had had of people in uniform by being able to play with a young Australian Army officer who was fluent in Albanian. The departmental staff, the Defence personnel, the paid staff and volunteers, who made the bricks and mortar of the safe havens into a human sanctuary, worked tirelessly for the Kosovars in their care. Many haven staff worked extraordinarily long hours: late nights and weekends were the norm rather than the exception, and many others worked full-time in addition to volunteering in the havens.

The haven centre managers who were responsible for the management of the havens and the coordination of the staff deserve special mention in this chamber. I want to include them in the record and I congratulate them all and thank them very warmly, on behalf of the Australian government and people, for their tireless work. They were: at East Hills, Peter Mitchell and Larry Tanner; at Singleton, Larry Tanner and Gerard Cheong; at Puckapunyal, Kevin Kinna and Megan McRae; at Portsea, Wendy Davenport and Adam Warzel. I have to mention Wendy Davenport here: at the reception at the opening of Portsea, she gave her whole speech in Albanian, and she is not an Albanian speaker. There were roars of applause. Mind you, she does speak German, and I think that helped her to get around some of the guttural sounds. It was a tremendous effort which really endeared her to the Kosovars in her care. At Hampstead, there was John Lindsay; at Leeuwin, Gerald Hitchcock and Paul Fahie; at Brighton, Genevieve Leonard; and at Bandiana, Robert Wait.

In making special mention of these people, I would also like to include in these thanks the efforts of all the members of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs based in the individual havens and also in the headquarters of the Safe Haven National Taskforce. I would also like to acknowledge the efforts of all members of the Department of Defence and the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. When a project of this magnitude is undertaken, not only does the workload of those directly involved increase but, by a ripple effect, the entire department is affected. So to the workmates of those directly involved, I say thank you for picking up the slack and the extra work that fell your way while your colleagues were out working in and organising the safe havens.

I do not have the luxury of time to mention every individual involved in Operation Safe Haven: if I did, the Senate would sit here until dawn; and they want to go home, I am sure, because the engines are rolling out at Canberra airport. I seek leave to incorporate into Hansard a list of the organisations that were involved with the havens, and I hope I have not missed any. There were individuals involved, but these were the main organisations. I am proud to have been involved in Operation Safe Haven and I hope that my words this afternoon have gone some way towards recognising the enormous debt of gratitude and thanks that we as a nation owe to those who have worked so hard in the establishment and management both of the Kosovar and East Timorese safe havens and to those who continue to do so as we still manage the remainder of the safe havens.

If, as I mentioned in my introduction, you are judged by your humanity to your fellow men and women, then those whom I have mentioned today and those involved in the safe havens will all indeed be judged richly.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Community Sector Support Scheme was split across the Health and Aged Care and the Family and Community Services portfolios in October 1998. Funding for organisations previously assisted under the part of the Community Sector Support Scheme that moved to my portfolio is now administered alongside other funding for similar agencies that came from other departments, in a `National Secretariat' Program. The responses to these questions relate to the period for which I have had portfolio responsibility for the Community Sector Support Scheme and its replacement Program.
(1) (a) The National Secretariat Program funds national bodies. It does not provide funding on a State-by-State basis.
(b) Total funding expected to be spent under the National Secretariat Program in 1999-2000 is $3,113,561.

(2) (a) Organisations may not necessarily seek funding under the National Secretariat Program + relevant applications can be directed there from other less appropriate funding programs. Approaches for assistance made by two organisations have been referred to the Program since October 1998 + the Lone Fathers Association Australia in June 1999 and the National Council of Single Mothers and their Children in October 1999.

(b) The Lone Fathers Association Australia was granted two years' seed funding from 1 July 1999. Approval in principle has been given for the National Council of Single Mothers and their Children to receive two years' seed funding, commencing shortly.

(c) The Lone Fathers Association Australia will receive $50,000 in the 1999-2000 financial year. The National Council of Single Mothers and their Children is expected to receive $36,538 pro rata from 11 October 1999 to 30 June, in the 1999-2000 financial year. Subject to meeting their contract requirements, both organisations will receive $50,000 in the 2000-2001 financial year.

(3) (a) The Department of Family and Community Services does not publicise the availability of funding under the National Secretariat Program. Availability of funding under the Community Sector Support Scheme was similarly not publicised.
(b) No.
(4) (a) The Department does not promote the National Secretariat Program. The Community Sector Support Scheme was similarly not promoted.
(b) Nil.
(5) (a) Eligibility criteria for continuing funding under the National Secretariat Program state that organisations should:
. be national in scope;
. be a not-for-profit community based organisation;
. be concerned with issues of relevance to the needs of the Australian community with respect to family and community services;

. act as a conduit for information flow between the Government and their membership, drawing together views on issues of relevance to their membership and providing a consultative mechanism for the Department;
. work on behalf of disadvantaged groups or others of interest or relevance to the Department, or on issues impacting on these groups;
. be able to demonstrate that it does not duplicate the representational work on behalf of its constituency, compared with other organisations in the National Secretariat Program;
. have limited capacity to be self-financing and to generate other income to run a national secretariat;

. not represent the interests of service providers unless it can demonstrate that no other organisation can be identified which fulfils the role of representing consumers in their field of interest; and

. have processes in place to effectively represent its members' view, as reflected in its reporting and communication channels, financial resources, external credibility, and internal accountability requirements.

The two organisations receiving `seed funding' under the National Secretariat Program have been required to move toward meeting the full eligibility criteria and to explore additional sources of funding to become more self-sufficient.
(b) These criteria are the same as applied to the previous Community Sector Support Scheme.
(6) (a) The Department of Family and Community Services assesses applications and advises the Minister on their merits and the extent of available funding.
(b) Approaches and rejections of applications for funding are decisions made by me as Minister for Family and Community Services.

(4) In addition to the ASA Board, who was provided with copies of the above reports.
(5) Can a copy be provided of each report provided to the ASA by Mercers Cullen Egan Dell.
(6) What was the increase in the average weekly ordinary time earnings index in each financial year since July 1995 used by the ASA in the calculation of salary increases for contract employees.
(7) What criteria does the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of ASA apply when appraising the performance of contract employees.

(8) How many such assessments have been made for each contract employee since 1 July 1995, and in each case: (a) how many of those appraisals have resulted in the payment of a bonus, or an increase in the officer's salary; and (b) on how many occasions has a contract employee failed to win a salary increase or bonus payment as a result of an appraisal by the CEO.
(9) What are the principles that are applied to contract employees' salary packages by the CEO.
(10) Since July 1995, on how many occasions has the CEO consulted the ASA Board in relation to the principles applying to contract employees' salary packages.

(12) When and why did the ASA Board delegate its power under section 42 of the Air Services Act 1995 in relation to the determination of staff remuneration to the CEO.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1)—(11) I am advised by Airservices Australia that the level of detail requested by Senator O'Brien would require an unreasonable application of scarce resources and has the potential to traverse areas normally covered by Privacy legislation.

However, as a general response, Airservices advise that aside from special one off consultancies, Mercers Cullen Egan Dell is engaged to provide a job evaluation methodology, position assessments, a computerised assessment tool and market information on an as required basis. The annual cost of these services ranges from $2000 to $16,000 per annum.
The information provided is used by the Airservices Human Resource Strategy Branch, the Chief Executive Officer and the Board Remuneration Committee, as appropriate.
The criteria applied to the performance appraisal of senior manager positions vary from position to position and are a matter between the CEO and the manager concerned.

(12) The Resolution which delegates authority under section 42 of the Air Services Act to the CEO was originally made by the CAA Board in May 1990 and was transferred to Airservices Australia by the Civil Aviation Legislation Amendment Act introduced by the Labor Government in 1995.

(13) The Airservices' Board Remuneration Committee comprises three Board members, including the Chairman and CEO. The committee meets as required (usually at least twice a year) and undertakes an annual review of CEO and Executive Director remuneration, provides guidance to the CEO in relation to Executive Committee member remuneration and considers succession arrangements for the most senior Executive positions in Airservices. Obviously, the CEO absents himself from discussions which involve review of his remuneration.

(2) In each case, and for each bonus payment, what weight was given to the average weekly ordinary time earnings index, advice from Mercers Cullen Egan Dell and a performance appraisal by the Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the ASA.

(3) What is the basis for the variation in the maximum value of each bonus, as advised in answer to question on notice no. 1265 (Senate Hansard, 27 September 1999, p.8802) and who determines, in each case, the maximum bonus available.

(4) What was the rating for each officer entitled to apply for a bonus payment against the five-point scale referred to in the answer to question on notice no.1265, for each bonus assessment made since July 1995.
(5) What does the following advice, given in answer to question on notice no.1265, actually mean: `The ratings given by Executive Managers may be normalised by the CEO'.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: I am advised by Airservices Australia that Senator O'Brien's line of questions in relation to Airservices' senior manager remuneration is very detailed and has the potential to traverse areas normally covered by Privacy legislation.

It has been a long-standing practice dating back to the last Labor Government that Government owned commercial enterprises, such as Airservices, introduce market based remuneration on condition that senior management jobs are advertised widely and filled on a merit basis, on the first occasion that they become vacant.

Under current Government guidelines, Airservices is required to manage relations with employees in a manner consistent with the Workplace Relations Act 1996, consult with the Remuneration Tribunal in determining the remuneration of their CEO, and comply with any specific requirements set by the Minister for Workplace Relations in consultation with the Minister and the Prime Minister, if appropriate.

Airservices has advised it meets these responsibilities and discharges its ongoing accountability requirements by appropriate Board supervision, retention of independent market advice from Mercers Cullen Egan Dell (in relation to the annual increase in total attainable remuneration, including the bonus) and annual performance assessments by the relevant supervisor, reviewed and, if necessary, altered by the CEO under "normalisation" arrangements.

Airservices reports the remuneration of executive managers in its annual report each year in accordance with the reporting guidelines issued by the Department of Finance. These virtually replicate the reporting requirements for companies under Corporations Law.
The Government believes that questions by Senator O'Brien that go beyond the information provided through these reporting arrangements would be an unreasonable call on resources.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on Thursday, 30 September 1999.

question.para: With reference to educational institutions which operated under the Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration of Providers and Financial Regulation) Act 1991 and the Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students: (a) over the past 12 months, as of 30 September 1999, how many people who came to Australia on student visas have been deported; and (b) what are the names of the educational institutions at which they were enrolled.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (a) The Department of Education, Training & Youth Affairs (DETYA) does not maintain this information, however the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA) has advised the following:
Visitors to Australia who are convicted criminals or a risk to national security are "deported". People visiting Australia who are in breach of the conditions of a student visa are "removed".
The number of student visa holders "removed" for the 12 months to 30 September 1999 include:
. 584 monitored departures, that is, unlawful citizens who were located and granted a bridging visa to depart Australia of their own volition;

. 68 supervised departures, that is, unlawful citizens who purchase their own ticket but are detained and escorted to the airport, granted a bridging visa at the airport in order to be lawful on departure from Australia; and
. 126 removal of detainees, that is, persons who are detained, have their ticket purchased by
DIMA and who are escorted to the airport and removed.
(b) DETYA does not maintain this information and DIMA has advised that their statistical reporting systems are unable to provide information on removals by educational institution.
